titleStmt.title: A perfect narrative of the battell of Knocknones, within the county of Cork and province of Munster, on Saturday, the thirteenth of November, betwixt the Parliaments forces under the command of the Lord Inchiquin, Lord President of Munster; and the forces of the Irish rebells under the Lord Taaff, / set downe by an officer of the Parliaments army, present and acting at the fight. Directed to an honorable Member of the House of Commons.
titleStmt.author: Officer of the Parliaments army.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A Perfect NARRATIVE OF THE BATTELL OF Knocknones, WITHIN THE COÆ²NTY Of Cork and Province of MunÅ¿ter, on Saturday, the Thirteenth of November, betwixt the Parliaments Forces under the Command of the Lord INCHIQUIN, Lord PreÅ¿ident of MunÅ¿ter; AND The forces of the IriÅ¿h Rebells under the Lord Taaff, Å¿et downe by an Officer of the Parliaments Army, preÅ¿ent and acting at the Fight.

p.hi: Directed to an Honorable Member of the HouÅ¿e of COMMONS.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for Robert BoÅ¿tock, in Pauls Church-yeard, at the Å¿igne of the Kings Head. 1647.

div.head: A Narrative of the Battell of KNOCKNONES.
div.p:
IT was now a Å¿eaÅ¿on as unapt for Action to the naked EngliÅ¿h, as opportune for the JriÅ¿h better inured and accommodated to the hardÅ¿hips of that Country, when the Lord Taff, Generall for the IriÅ¿h, advanced towards the EngliÅ¿h Quarters, with a DeÅ¿igne to block up, or diÅ¿treÅ¿s them in their GarriÅ¿ons, wherein it being diÅ¿cerned, that hee might prevalently proceed to their deÅ¿truction, if a Å¿eaÅ¿onable oppoÅ¿ition were not given; It was at a CounÅ¿ell of Warre Å¿ummoned by the PreÅ¿edent, long debated whether to iÅ¿Å¿ue forth of our GarriÅ¿ons to encounter this approaching Torrent or not, and at length after an earneÅ¿t endeavour of divers to the contrary, reÅ¿olved to be more conÅ¿iÅ¿tent with our Å¿afeties to make head againÅ¿t the Rebells in the field, then to Å¿uffer them to come within our Quarters, and Å¿o diÅ¿able us either to joyne together in an offencive, or Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿t together in a defenÅ¿ive poÅ¿ture, In purÅ¿uance of which reÅ¿olution, The Army (being by the generall vote, and the PreÅ¿idents Orders drawne together at Moyallo) marchched on the Twelfth of this InÅ¿tant (after a due diÅ¿charge
of thoÅ¿e pious invocations and exerciÅ¿es of addreÅ¿Å¿es to the Divine Providence which the PreÅ¿ident had injoyned) to a place called Gariduff (in EngliÅ¿h Blask-gardens) the Rebells encamping at Knocknones within two miles of us; but the day Å¿o far Å¿pent, as that it was not held fit to make any attempt then upon them; About the evening came a Trumpet from the Lord Taff with a Letter to the PreÅ¿ident, in theÅ¿e words,

body.p:
THe delay of my not Å¿ending to you a returne of your laÅ¿t Letter by your Trumpet, was occaÅ¿ioned by my Å¿tay for my Artillery, which being come, I tell your LordÅ¿hip, That Captaine Courtepp very much magnifying the Excellency of your Foot, I offered (more for recreation then with a Å¿uÅ¿pition that it might breake your Army) That a ThouÅ¿and or two of mine Å¿hould (when ever you made an indifferent appointment,) Å¿ight with a like number of yours; which I am now ready to performe in this place; And if you pleaÅ¿e to draw the Remaine of your Army hither, I will look upon you, and certainly neither of our Parties will want the gallantry of Å¿econding their ingaged friends. Our quartell is to preÅ¿erve the Kings IntereÅ¿ts, which all of us with the hazard of our lives will maintaine againÅ¿t my oppoÅ¿ition; And when I conÅ¿ider, that by the deÅ¿truction of your party, I may be in the more unmoleÅ¿ted Condition to Å¿erve him, be certaine your invitation to battell is neceptably received by me. I know that in your LordÅ¿hips Army there are a great many Gentlemen which have been very faithfull to their King, and ãâ¦ã is your LordÅ¿hips, practiÅ¿e to abuÅ¿e them by ãâã them in a Å¿ervice to deÅ¿tructive to His MajeÅ¿ties
Rights. And pray, my Lord, doe not delude them by detracting this Army, who are unalterably, and without any hope of perticular benefit, determined to looÅ¿e themÅ¿elves, or reÅ¿tore (as much as in them lies) the King to His former greatneÅ¿Å¿e; This is truth, and it proceeds cordially from

div.p: To which the Lord PreÅ¿ident returned.

body.p: MY LORD, I have received your Letter, by your Trumpeter, and your LordÅ¿hip might before this have perceived that I was not ignorant where your Army lay, had not the approach of night Å¿canted me of time to march up unto you; And being you have performed as much as I deÅ¿ire in bringing your Army hither, I Å¿hall not deÅ¿ire you to looÅ¿e any advantage you have in numbers of men, being your offer was onely made for Recreation: You are pleaÅ¿ed to Å¿ay your quarrell is chiefly to preÅ¿erve the Kings IntereÅ¿t, and becauÅ¿e I beleeve it will little avail me to offer ReaÅ¿ons to convince you of the contray, I Å¿hall deferre the diÅ¿pute untill wee meet in the morning, when I beleeve theÅ¿e Gentlemen whom yee Å¿uppoÅ¿e to bee deluded by me, will by Gods help uÅ¿e Rhetorick that will better conduce to that end, to which I Å¿hall refer your LordÅ¿hip for Å¿atisfaction, being reÅ¿olved to contribute there in to the endeavours of

div.p:
This night wee lodged in a wood which equally affoarded both Å¿ecurity and convenience unto the Å¿ouldiers. The word was to the Foot (Pray) to the HouÅ¿e (Prevaile;) and this night Å¿ome ãâ¦ã was obÅ¿erved in the nature of ãâã early in the mornning
we began to prepare (the light giving us now a clear manifeÅ¿tation of what was to be done) the enemy was drawn up upon a hil about two Myles of called Knoknones, which being of great advantage to them. The Lord PreÅ¿ident (if poÅ¿Å¿ible) to withdraw them from it Å¿ent this Letter to the Rebels Gene all.

p.hi: Here is a very faire piece of ground betwixt your LordÅ¿hips Army and ours, one this Å¿ide the brooke; whether if you pleaÅ¿e to advance, we will do the like; we do not Å¿o much doubt the gallantry of your reÅ¿olution, as to thinke you will not come, but give you this notice, to the end you may Å¿ee wee do stand upon no advantage of ground, and are willing to diÅ¿pute our Qaurrel upon indifferent tearms; being conÅ¿ident that the juÅ¿tneÅ¿Å¿e of our CauÅ¿e wilbe this day made manifeÅ¿t by the Lord, and that your LordÅ¿hips judgment will be rectified concerning

div.p: To which the Lord Taaff returned verball anÅ¿wer, that hee was not Å¿o little a Å¿ouldier, as not to improve any advantage he had, of ground or otherwiÅ¿e, which he doubted not the PreÅ¿ident would doe in like eaÅ¿e.

The reaÅ¿on as we learned afterwards by Å¿ome of their men taken priÅ¿oners, (beÅ¿ides the advantage of ground being a Å¿teep hill) why the Lord Taaff Å¿o pertinaciouÅ¿ly Å¿tuck to that place was this.
There was a certaine old blind PropheÅ¿ie running amongÅ¿t the IriÅ¿h, which converted into EngliÅ¿h rymes like their old bard Å¿peakes thus.

q.l: By whom the EngliÅ¿h Lord Å¿hall fall
Bloud Å¿hall aÅ¿cend to the legges Å¿mall
The place wee Knoknones doe call.

div.p: Which was by the Lord Taaff applyed to himÅ¿elf, for that the hill whereon he Å¿tood was called Knocknones, and his AnceÅ¿tors had the lands of Mack. Donagh given by the Kings of Enland in reward of their Å¿ervice performed againÅ¿t he Rebells here, their Leuiftenant Generall Sr. Alexander Mac Donnell known vulgarly by the name of Colkitta, was unwilling to have the fight performed on that day (upon a Å¿uperÅ¿tious obÅ¿ervation,; for that he was exceedingly afraid of Saturns malevolent influence, that day being to him criticall) the former name of this place was antiquated almoÅ¿t this laÅ¿t age, the name of it now being EngliÅ¿hmans hill, as it proved upon this happy and Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿efull day.

The Lord Taaff therefore reÅ¿olving obÅ¿tinately to adhere to his choÅ¿en ground, the Lord PreÅ¿ident calling a CounÅ¿ell of War to adviÅ¿e whether it were expedient to aÅ¿Å¿ault them on Å¿uch a diÅ¿advantageous place (the wind freinding them likewiÅ¿e, and their numbers almoÅ¿t doubling ours) but the Å¿ence of our preÅ¿ent condition quickly reÅ¿olved this Å¿cruple, it being to no purpoÅ¿e to have advanced hitherto, if wee Å¿hould proceed no further, and for the Å¿ucceÅ¿s to put our Å¿elves upon the mercy of God. It is not to be forgotten here that before the CounÅ¿ell, the Lord PreÅ¿ident commanded that God Å¿hould be Å¿ought by prayer, for our direction in this needful time of trouble. The word given on our Å¿ide was Victory, the mark a branch of new broome in our hats, wherewith our Quarters then abounded. The
enemies mark was a Å¿trawen rope about their hats; their Word was God and St. Paterick, they having forgotten how lately their contry St. had failed them; (for that was the word when we put them to the Å¿word at CaÅ¿hel) their numbers conÅ¿iÅ¿ted as themÅ¿elves gave out 9000. Foote. and a 1000. HorÅ¿e, but by liÅ¿t found afterwardes in the Leiuftenant Generals pocket, they were muÅ¿tred in the field 7464 foot, and 1076, horÅ¿e. beÅ¿ides Officers: our Army was neere 4000 Foote, and 1200 horÅ¿e, the enimie ranging their battell in a plain front, all along the hill, that Å¿o they might ingage all their force together, their foot were drawn into nine diviÅ¿ions, of which the greater part by much was Pike, wing'd with three bodies of HorÅ¿e on each Å¿ide, beÅ¿ide reÅ¿erves; our foot whoÅ¿e number was by half the leÅ¿Å¿e, were marÅ¿hald into three deviÅ¿ions, whereof two parts of three were Muskets, the right and left Wing of HorÅ¿e were made of 13 bodies of HorÅ¿e, 7 on the right wing, and 6 on the left (with their ReÅ¿erves;) Both Armies thus drawn up,

The Rebels held firmly (their firÅ¿t reÅ¿olution) not to parte with their Å¿tation, but that we Å¿hould either not fight at all, or do it upon theÅ¿e unequall tearms, the wind was for the Rebells, the Lord PreÅ¿ident (whoÅ¿e Rivall no man can be in this piece of glory, it being indeed in all mens judgements, under God, the gaining of the day on our Å¿ide) throughly weighing their numbred ground and Comodity of the place, above us, all which he conÅ¿idered of too much moment they might be to turn the Seale in the Ballance of War, thought of a way of forcing them to that which they would not willingly be drawn to, to leave the ground, and diÅ¿compoÅ¿e their preÅ¿ent forme, that Å¿o (we might have the advantage in that diÅ¿order) to aÅ¿Å¿ault them; and this he effected thus;

He drew the left wing of his battle from the ground, wherein he at firÅ¿t placed them, making them move into a place of fallow ground more leftward, as if he would get upon the enemies backs on that Å¿ide, and Commanded his right wing to wave a little that way too, as if he went with all his Force to aÅ¿Å¿ail them in that one place. The Rebels carefull enough to Å¿upport their own deÅ¿igne, had a watchfull eye upon all our motions; and by this laÅ¿t, imagining they might be charged in the Rear, or Å¿urcharged with the multitudes of our men at one place, the train of the Lord PreÅ¿idents Plot immediately took; for they breaking their firÅ¿t form, parted with their Å¿tands: LikewiÅ¿e drawing moÅ¿t of their Forces to Å¿uccour their right wing, by varying the Å¿cene of their ground, we got theÅ¿e advantages. The wind was made an indifferent arbiter, the aÅ¿cent of the hill not Å¿o Å¿teep, and onely the Sunne was now a neuter to ripen the Fruit of this DeÅ¿ign quite, which was now more then green. The Lord PreÅ¿ident commanded two pieces of Artillery to be drawn to play on their right wing, and if any diÅ¿order thereby hapned, our HorÅ¿e and Foot were in that nick to fall on: our right wing having obÅ¿erved the left of theirs, made thin with Å¿ome confuÅ¿ion likewiÅ¿e in Å¿ending relief to their friends, had command to reÅ¿ume their firÅ¿t Å¿tations, and to incline further to the right hand (as our left wing had done before to the left) as if they likewiÅ¿e intended to Å¿urpriÅ¿e the Rebels on the back; to prevent which, the Rebels reÅ¿olved immediatdly to fall on: to this end they advanced with their HorÅ¿e before their Foot, to charge; but that errour being Å¿oon eÅ¿pied by ours, our Å¿hot were commanded preÅ¿ently to advance under the Å¿helter of a Ditch that parted them and us, who poured Å¿uch Å¿howers of hail upon them (that it proving a funerall peall to many) the reÅ¿t retired foul, and routed their own Foot. This their neighbours eÅ¿pying, followed their example, and Å¿o their main body of Foot, and left wing of HorÅ¿e ran clean
way, and our HorÅ¿e followed after them in the chaÅ¿e: But God willing to mingle a little gall with the Å¿weet cup he had before given us (that Å¿o we might be contented to receive every thing at his hand) was pleaÅ¿ed, that part of ground which was aÅ¿Å¿igned for our left wing, was not Å¿o convenient for horÅ¿e, yet to be accepted (where there was no choice of better) but very defenceable by Foote, by reaÅ¿on of Å¿ome incloÅ¿ures and ditches, and a lane near adjacent; there the Lord PreÅ¿ident made the bounds of his Foot, but they by their vallour (if not raÅ¿hneÅ¿Å¿e rather) fancying to themÅ¿elves Å¿ome imaginary advantage, preÅ¿t further, and Å¿o clouded us a little with the Å¿moake of their Å¿hot, that the right wing of the Rebels Army which was led by Sir Alexander Mack-Donnel, alias Colkitto. the Rebels Lieutenant generall, on whom our guns playing fiercely (to prevent that danger and performe Å¿ome notable Å¿ervice, as he had promiÅ¿ed with his Red-Å¿hankes) came thundring downe without the leaÅ¿t Å¿ence of danger, even the Rebels horÅ¿e on their right winge advancing with thoÅ¿e foot, were charged by their oppoÅ¿ite horÅ¿e on our left wing, and routed; who following hard upon them, the Rebels foot Å¿lipt in undecerned of them upon our foot, whoÅ¿e forwardneÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿eeing the enemies horÅ¿e routed had left their defenÅ¿ive Å¿tage which they might with eaÅ¿e and Å¿afely have maintained; and rouling downe like a Torrent impetuouÅ¿ly on our foot, routed our forlorne hope, by which meanes our foot being our numbred the Enemy began to have the execution of them; poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿t two of our guns, and one of them being loaded, diÅ¿charged it againÅ¿t us, and Å¿o tearing down all before them got to our waggons and there fel a plundering had it not bin for this diÅ¿aÅ¿ter, without doubt, we had bought a moÅ¿t perfect & glorious victory at the eaÅ¿ieÅ¿t rate that might be without the loÅ¿Å¿e as is imagined of ten men, but this coÅ¿t Å¿ome fifty of our common men their lives, and divers of out galanteÅ¿t Commanders not being able to Å¿tay their men
nor willing to run along with them, there gloriouÅ¿ly Å¿acrificed their lives, rather chuÅ¿ing to die, though almoÅ¿t deÅ¿erted of all, then to give the leaÅ¿t ground back to Å¿o barbarous and cruell Rebels. The Lord PreÅ¿ident was but newly parted from the left wing being on the right, where he ioyfully Å¿aw a Victory on the nick of gaining, by the totall diÅ¿comfiture of that part of the Enemy: but looking towards our left wing, there his eyes were preÅ¿ented with the rufull Å¿pectacle of his mens Å¿laughters and the Rebels overturning all before them even to our wagons, he immediately poÅ¿ted down Å¿om Regiments of Foot, and a troop or two of HorÅ¿e, which had been there for ReÅ¿erves, and not come upon the charge: TheÅ¿e coming down fell upon the Rebels in their return from our Baggage, where they made there lives, pay the price of their inÅ¿olent attempt by putting the greateÅ¿t part of them to the, Å¿word, amongÅ¿t whom fell Sir Alexander Mack Donnell and his Lievtenant Colonel. And thus by Gods help and the wiÅ¿dome and vallour of our Generall, Commanders and Souldiers, a glorious victory was gained over the Rebels, the chaÅ¿e was followed every way by our Foot and HorÅ¿e, but HorÅ¿e eÅ¿pecially, for they were too light for our footmen, all over the Countrey, till night hindred the further proÅ¿ecution when a retreat being Å¿ounded for that time the Lord PreÅ¿ident and his Officers in the field with their Souldiers, gave thanks to God for his extraordinary great mercy, and deliverance. The Å¿laughter was not made an end with that day, for the next day our HorÅ¿e ranged the Countrey and found divers; and the foot hunted the woods, and bogs, and by that means found many of the enemy which were put to the Å¿word upon the place.

The Å¿torm fell Å¿ore upon their foot, the Country who Å¿hould know beÅ¿t report five thouÅ¿and to be Å¿laine, there could not be leÅ¿Å¿e then foure thouÅ¿and, we recovered neer 6000 Armes, 38 Collours of Foote, with Å¿ome Cornets of HorÅ¿e, wee alÅ¿o recovered
their Waggons and all their Ammunition, tooke the Lord Taaff's their Generals tent, field bed, and Cabinet wherein are papers of concernment, importing much of this Å¿ervice of Ireland, which is to be delivered into the HouÅ¿e. In it was found likewiÅ¿e his CommiÅ¿Å¿ion from the Supreame Councell for being Generall of the Forces of MunÅ¿ter; Å¿o that by the loÅ¿Å¿e of his Army he wants Men to command, and of his CommiÅ¿Å¿ion, power to command men: On our part were Å¿laine in that unhappy rout of our left wing, Å¿ome noble and gallant Officers, Sir William Bridges Collonell of HorÅ¿e, Collonell Gray, Major Browne, Sir Robert Travers the Judge-Advocate was killed at our Baggage, a Captaine or two, Reformades, and Å¿ome other Officers of inferiour rank, when the Å¿word had Å¿ufficiently quenched his thirÅ¿t of bloud, then in a cooler vaine, mercy began to take place, and theÅ¿e PerÅ¿ons undermentioned were taken PriÅ¿oners.

list.head: A LiÅ¿t of the PriÅ¿oners taken.
EnÅ¿ignes.
list.item:
EnÅ¿igne Lacy:
Troopers, 14
Serieants, 9
Corporalls 7
Souldiers, 22
Chirurgions. 6

list.head: Gentlemen of the Countrey.
list.item: Afterwards found out with the Souldiers,

div.p: Divers other Captaines and Officers were made priÅ¿oners, who remaining yet in the Souldiers hands unbrought in, could not be inrold in this liÅ¿t, on our part were taken priÅ¿oners, Lieutenant Collonell CriÅ¿pe, who is now releaÅ¿t and with us for an Officer of theirs of like quality, beÅ¿ides one Lieutenant more, here to give you juÅ¿t accompt what every Officer and Soldier performed, (except that Å¿mall party which unfortunately fled, would Å¿well this relation too much, and inquire the actors modeÅ¿ty, who deÅ¿ire the glory Å¿hould be aÅ¿cribed to God, themÅ¿elves being but imployed as inÅ¿truments. For the Officers, & amongÅ¿t the forwardeÅ¿t of them, Collonel Temple, who had Å¿een them performe this dayes Å¿ervice, would have thought them worthy of a better reward, then having conquered all their enemies abroad, to go home, and be conquered themÅ¿elves by their owne wants, each Souldier honoured God by his vallour, and none diÅ¿honoured themÅ¿elves. The Lord PreÅ¿ident has not yet made an end of his victory, for he is proÅ¿ecuting it vigorouÅ¿ly, by reducing all the Country into Contribution, where he marches notwithÅ¿tanding the violence of the weather, and the practiÅ¿es of Å¿ome to draw the Souldier to a mutinous crying out, Home, Home it being now a deepe Å¿now, and his men almoÅ¿t naked, that Å¿o the Province may be Å¿ubdued, and the Rebells diÅ¿abled to draw Å¿uddenly to a head againe, which if it pleaÅ¿e the Divine Providence to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t us with Å¿eaÅ¿onable Å¿upplies, we Å¿hall uÅ¿e all poÅ¿Å¿ible and effectuall meanes to prevent.

list.head: A brief of the Å¿lain and taken.
